CHAPTER ΙΙ l.

oF THE WORK FURNACE.

NEAR the wall, by the window, on the left side of the person sitting, a piece of wood is fixed in the ground (three¹ feet in length) in width two and in thickness scarcely two fingers, which, when it is firmly fixed, may have a perforation in the midst of the size of a finger, four fingers high above the ground. Let it have also in front a straight piece of wood joined to it, and fixed with wooden pegs, four fingers in breadth, and the length of which is equal to the large piece of wood. In front of this you fasten another wood of equal breadth and length, so that between these two woods there may be a space of four fingers, and fasten that outside by two or three stakes3 and taking clay, not beaten, nor mixed with water, but newly dug up, put at first a little of it into this space, and compress it strongly with a rounded piece of wood, then more, and again beat it; and do thus until two parts of this space are filled, and leave the third empty. Then take away the wood in front, and with a long knife cut the clay evenly in front and on the top, then with a thin piece of wood beat it strongly. After this take clay beaten and mixed with horse dung, and make the furnace and its hearth, covering the wall that it may not be burned by the fire, and with a slender piece of wood perforate the clay through the opening which is in the wood behind. In this manner compose all

smith’s furnaces.
